conditions.name: Common Cold
conditions.description: A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, primarily affecting the nose and throat. Usually mild and self-limiting, lasting 7-10 days.

naturalRemedies.notes: May reduce duration and severity of symptoms
Antiviral properties, especially when taken at first signs
Soothes throat and has antimicrobial properties

warnings: Seek medical attention if fever exceeds 101.3°F (38.5°C) for more than 3 days
Consult doctor if symptoms worsen or don't improve after 10 days
Seek immediate care for difficulty breathing or severe chest pain
conditions.prevalence: Extremely common; adults average 2-3 colds per year

conditions.name: Insomnia
conditions.description: A sleep disorder characterized by difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or experiencing non-restorative sleep despite adequate opportunity for sleep.
symptoms: Waking up frequently during the night

naturalRemedies.notes: Reduces sleep latency and improves sleep quality
Calming effect, particularly when combined with other herbs
Gentle sedative, safe for long-term use

lifestyleModifications: Create dark, quiet, cool sleep environment
Regular exercise (but not close to bedtime)
warnings: Consult healthcare provider if insomnia persists for more than a month
May be a symptom of underlying medical or mental health conditions
Avoid driving or operating machinery if severely sleep-deprived
conditions.prevalence: Affects 10-30% of adults; more common in women and older adults

conditions.name: Indigestion (Dyspepsia)
conditions.description: Discomfort or pain in the upper abdomen, often occurring during or after eating. May include feelings of fullness, bloating, or nausea.

naturalRemedies.notes: Effective for nausea and digestive discomfort
Relaxes digestive tract muscles, reduces gas

lifestyleModifications: Don't lie down immediately after eating
warnings: Seek medical attention for severe or persistent pain
Consult doctor if experiencing unexplained weight loss
Get immediate care for chest pain, shortness of breath, or vomiting blood
conditions.prevalence: Affects approximately 25% of the population annually

medicinalPlants.description: A flowering plant native to North America, recognized by its distinctive purple-pink petals and spiky center cone. Used traditionally by Native Americans for various ailments.

activeCompounds.name: Polysaccharides
activeCompounds.description: Complex carbohydrates that may stimulate immune function

preparations.instructions: Steep 1-2 teaspoons dried herb in hot water for 10-15 minutes
preparations.duration: Drink 3 times daily at first sign of cold
3 times daily for up to 10 days

dosage.standardDose: 300-500 mg dried herb extract, 3 times daily
dosage.notes: Most effective when taken at first sign of symptoms; not recommended for continuous use beyond 8 weeks

contraindications: Allergies to plants in Asteraceae family

drugInteractions.interaction: May counteract effects of immunosuppressive medications
May increase caffeine levels and side effects

sustainability.notes: Widely cultivated; wild populations stable but prefer cultivated sources

medicinalPlants.description: A perennial flowering plant with sweet-smelling pink or white flowers but a distinctively pungent-smelling root, which is the part used medicinally.

activeCompounds.name: Valerenic acid
activeCompounds.description: Thought to inhibit breakdown of GABA in the brain

preparations.instructions: Steep 2-3 grams of dried root in hot water for 10-15 minutes

dosage.standardDose: 400-900 mg extract taken 30 minutes to 2 hours before bedtime
dosage.notes: Effects may take 2-4 weeks of regular use to become apparent

sideEffects: Morning grogginess (if taken late at night)

sustainability.notes: Commonly cultivated in Europe and North America

medicinalPlants.description: A delicate annual plant with white daisy-like flowers and a sweet, apple-like scent. One of the most widely used medicinal herbs.

activeCompounds.name: Apigenin
activeCompounds.description: Flavonoid with anti-anxiety and sedative properties

activeCompounds.name: Chamazulene
activeCompounds.description: Anti-inflammatory compound formed during steam distillation

preparations.instructions: Steep 1 tablespoon dried flowers in hot water for 5-10 minutes, covered
Dilute and apply topically or use in aromatherapy

dosage.standardDose: 1-4 cups of tea daily, or 400-1600 mg extract
dosage.maximumDailyDose: Not established; generally considered safe in typical amounts
dosage.notes: Cover tea while steeping to preserve volatile oils

contraindications: Allergy to plants in Asteraceae family
sideEffects: Allergic reactions (in those allergic to ragweed, chrysanthemums, or marigolds)

medicinalPlants.description: A flowering plant whose rhizome (underground stem) is widely used as a spice and folk medicine. Has a warm, spicy flavor and aroma.

activeCompounds.name: Gingerols
activeCompounds.description: Primary bioactive compounds with anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects

activeCompounds.name: Shogaols
activeCompounds.description: Formed when ginger is dried; more potent than gingerols

preparations.instructions: Steep 1 teaspoon fresh grated ginger in hot water for 10 minutes
preparations.duration: Drink as needed, up to 3-4 cups daily

dosage.standardDose: 1-3 grams daily of fresh ginger or 250-1000 mg extract
dosage.notes: For nausea, take at first sign of symptoms

sustainability.notes: Widely cultivated in tropical regions worldwide
